between belly dancing and cabaret, was I saw my first ever pair of ISIS wings, would you
like to explain what an ISIS wing, where it comes from and what it looks like, because
even as we sit in the swicker office there's a whole bevy of them behind us in amazing
colours, so I hadn't seen one before and I just thought oh.
Yeah, yeah, well the ISIS wings, it's a belly dance prop, it doesn't actually have any historic
basis in belly dance, it's a completely modern prop that dancers use, it's a pleated, permanent
pleated cape which goes around the neck and it will open out to 360 degrees, so it will
make a complete circle, at least a decent one will make a complete circle or near enough,
so when you open the sides of the cape have got sticks in them, so when you lift the sticks
up you can make this big circle and you can make lovely shapes with your cape as you're
dancing.
Yeah, it was interesting because immediately I saw a point of contact with carnival and
one of my gurus, even to this day of creative carnival, is a man who revolutionised carnival
in Trinidad, a man called Peter Minchel who went on to do fabulous things, he reintroduced
the artist back into the Trinidad carnival, his group were part of not one but two Olympic
Games ceremony openings and his breakthrough movement was creating a costume called the
Hummingbird where you had those wings and you had the extension of them through the
hand and through the sticks and immediately I thought, oh my gosh that looks carnival-esque
for me and the fact that the Isis wings that you were performing with and which we have
adopted in a lot of our work were made in bright, shiny, scintillating colours which
really caught the light and were magical, so that was immediately one thing I was thinking
oh my goodness we've got to get some of those in the wonderful world of carnival, I think
originally we ended up importing some via a belly dance organiser in South Wales but
importing them from Egypt. Yeah that was through Sue, that was through Sue who calls herself
Sophina in Newport and she's married to an Egyptian. This is just how times have changed
